questiontext.text:
Calculation of Fourier coefficients

Consider the Fourier series for a function \(f(t)\) of period \(2\pi\): \[ f(t) = \dfrac{a_0}{2} + \sum_{n = 1}^\infty ( a_n \cos nt + b_n \sin nt). \] To obtain the coefficients \( a_n\) \( (n = 1, 2, 3, \dots ) \), we multiply both sides by \( \cos mt\) where \(m\) is some positive integer and integrate both sides from \( -\pi\) to \( \pi \).

For the left-hand side we obtain \[ \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi }f(t)\cos mt \hspace{0.15cm}dt. \] For the right-hand side we obtain \[ \dfrac{a_0}{2} \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi } \cos mt \hspace{0.15cm}dt + \sum_{n=1}^\infty \left\{ a_n \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi } \cos nt \cos mt \hspace{0.15cm}dt + \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi } \sin nt \cos mt \hspace{0.15cm}dt \right\} \] The first integral is zero.

Using the orthogonality relations all the integrals in the summation give zero except for the case \(n = m\) when \[ \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi } \cos^2 mt \hspace{0.15cm}dt = \pi. \] Hence \[ \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi }f(t)\cos mt \hspace{0.15cm}dt = a_m \pi\] from which the coefficient \(a_m\) can be obtained.

Rewriting \(m\) as \(n\) we get \[ a_n = \dfrac{1}{\pi} \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi }f(t)\cos nt \hspace{0.15cm}dt \hspace{1cm} \text{for } n = 1, 2, 3, \dots \]

Note that this formula works for \(n = 0\) (but we must remember that the constant term is \( \dfrac{a_0}{2}\).)

Thus \(a_n = 2 \times \text{ average value of } f(t) \cos nt\) over one period.

A similar calculation can be performed to find the \(b_n\) coefficients.Instead of multiplying the Fourier series by \( \cos mt\) and integrating as above, we multiply by \(\sin mt\) and integrate. Indeed, we have \[ \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi }f(t)\sin mt \hspace{0.15cm}dt = \dfrac{a_0}{2} \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi } \sin mt \hspace{0.15cm}dt + \sum_{n=1}^\infty \left\{ a_n \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi } \cos nt \sin mt \hspace{0.15cm}dt + \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi } \sin nt \sin mt \hspace{0.15cm}dt \right\} . \] All terms on the right-hand side integrate to zero except for the case \(n = m\) where \[ \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi } b_m \sin^2 mt \hspace{0.15cm}dt = b_m \pi \] Relabelling \(m\) as \(n\) gives \[b_n = \dfrac{1}{\pi} \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi } f(t) \sin nt \hspace{0.15cm}dt \hspace{1cm} n = 1, 2, 3, \dots \] (There is no Fourier coefficient \(b_0\).)

Clearly \(b_n = 2 \times \text{ average value of } f(t)\sin nt\) over one period.
